metadata.name: Ecological Principles for Restoration Reasoning
metadata.description: Core ecological rules and scientific knowledge for AI-assisted restoration planning

succession_and_recovery.name: Succession & Recovery
succession_and_recovery.description: Understanding natural ecosystem recovery patterns and when to intervene
key_concepts: Natural regeneration vs active planting decisions
Pioneer species establish first, facilitating climax community
Fire-adapted species follow predictable succession patterns
Seed bank persistence varies by species and disturbance severity
decision_rules: If burn severity < 50% AND seed source within 100m → natural regeneration likely
If burn severity > 70% AND no seed source within 500m → active planting required
Pioneer shrubs (Ceanothus, manzanita) establish within 1-3 years post-fire
Conifer regeneration may take 5-20 years to establish
california_specific: Coast redwood resprouts from base even after severe fire
Chaparral species have fire-stimulated seed germination
Mixed conifer forests historically had 10-25 year fire return intervals
High-severity fire patches should be limited to <15% of landscape

connectivity_and_corridors.name: Connectivity & Corridors
connectivity_and_corridors.description: Maintaining landscape connectivity for species movement and gene flow
key_concepts: Fragmented habitats need linkages for population viability
Wildlife corridors enable species movement and migration
Gene flow prevents inbreeding depression
Connectivity increases resilience to climate change
decision_rules: Prioritize restoration sites that connect existing habitat patches
Riparian corridors provide multi-species connectivity
Minimum corridor width: 100m for small mammals, 500m+ for large carnivores
Stepping stone habitats can supplement continuous corridors
california_specific: Sierra Nevada to Coast Range connections critical for wide-ranging species
Highway underpasses and overpasses for wildlife crossing
Salmon need connected stream networks (dam removal, fish passage)
Mountain lion habitat connectivity increasingly fragmented

hydrology_and_wetlands.name: Hydrology & Wetlands
hydrology_and_wetlands.description: Water flow restoration as foundation for ecosystem recovery
key_concepts: Wetland restoration requires water flow restoration first
Floodplains provide critical ecosystem services
Riparian buffers protect water quality
Post-fire debris flows alter stream channels
decision_rules: Restore hydrology BEFORE planting wetland vegetation
Maintain minimum 30m riparian buffer from streams
Reduce sediment loading post-fire through erosion control
Allow natural flood regimes where possible
california_specific: California has lost >90% of historic wetlands
Vernal pools are globally rare and host endemic species
Drought cycles require drought-tolerant riparian species
post_fire_hydrology: Hydrophobic soil layer forms after high-severity fire
Debris flow risk highest in first 1-2 years post-fire
Stream flashiness increases after watershed burns
Mulching and erosion control critical on steep slopes

soil_and_nutrients.name: Soil & Nutrients
soil_and_nutrients.description: Soil health as foundation for restoration success
key_concepts: Degraded soil limits restoration success
Legumes fix atmospheric nitrogen
Mycorrhizal networks essential for forest recovery
Soil organic matter takes decades to rebuild
decision_rules: Test soil before restoration to identify limitations
Include nitrogen-fixing species (Ceanothus, lupine) in early plantings
Inoculate with native mycorrhizae when replanting conifers
Avoid soil compaction during restoration activities
california_specific: Serpentine soils require specialized native species
Fire volatilizes nitrogen but ash provides other nutrients
Ceanothus species are important nitrogen-fixers post-fire
post_fire_soil: High-severity fire consumes soil organic matter
Soil heating kills mycorrhizal fungi to 10cm depth
Ash layer provides short-term nutrient pulse
Erosion risk highest before vegetation establishes

keystone_species_and_trophic_cascades.name: Keystone Species & Trophic Cascades
keystone_species_and_trophic_cascades.description: Key species that disproportionately influence ecosystem function
key_concepts: Removing invasive predators allows native prey recovery
Reintroducing native pollinators enhances reproduction
Beavers are ecosystem engineers that create wetlands
Oak trees are keystone mast providers for wildlife
decision_rules: Identify and protect keystone species in restoration planning
Remove invasive species before planting natives
Plant species that support native pollinators
Consider trophic interactions, not just individual species

california_keystone_species.role: Marine nutrients to forest via carcasses
Soil aeration, prey base for raptors

invasive_species_priority: Scotch broom outcompetes native shrubs post-fire
Sudden Oak Death (Phytophthora) kills oaks and tanoaks

climate_adaptation.name: Climate Adaptation
climate_adaptation.description: Planning restoration for future climate conditions
key_concepts: Choose species suited to future climate, not just current
Assisted migration for climate refugees
Build resilience to drought, fire, and floods
Genetic diversity for adaptive capacity
decision_rules: Use climate projections (2050, 2100) when selecting species
Source seeds from slightly warmer/drier populations
Favor drought-tolerant genotypes within native species
Maintain genetic diversity in planting stock
adaptation_strategies: Shift species selection toward warmer-adapted ecotypes
Increase spacing to reduce drought competition
Favor fire-resilient species and forest structures
Prepare for type-conversion (forest → shrubland) in some areas

community_and_cultural_ecology.name: Community & Cultural Ecology
community_and_cultural_ecology.description: Integrating human communities and traditional knowledge
key_concepts: Traditional ecological knowledge (TEK) is valuable
Indigenous stewardship practices often fire-based
Local livelihoods depend on ecosystem services
Community engagement improves restoration success
decision_rules: Consult with local tribes on restoration plans
Incorporate traditional burning practices where appropriate
Plan for sustainable harvest of restoration products
Engage local community in monitoring and stewardship
california_indigenous_practices: Cultural burning by California tribes for millennia
Acorn harvest and oak woodland management
Basketry plants (sedge, willow) need fire management
economic_opportunities: Ecosystem restoration jobs in rural communities
Carbon credits and ecological services payments
